J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> David Saff wrote:
>
> > However, if the only way to know the number of lines in this
> > hypothetical data file was to read it, this requirement would force
> > either two passes through the file, or storing the whole file in
> > memory.  Do you think this would be a hangup often in scenarios you've
> > seen?  How did you solve such problems in JUnit 3?
>
> As far as I can tell from the community, they didn't. (I never
> personally dealt with the problem.) That was one thing they didn't like
> about JUnit: running out of memory when constructing test suites.

There's at least two ways that one could handle this issue in JUnit 4 
out of the box:

1) Write a Runner that returned a null plan, with a RunListener that 
didn't care about the plan, such as the default command-line 
RunListener.  However, the current Eclipse runner would fall over if 
given such a request, as would the JUnit 3 forward compatibility layer.

2) Since all the Plan needs is a list of test names, just create a list 
of names that is easy to remember, and large enough to definitely cover 
the data space, such as the numbers from 1 to 10000.  For example, use 
the built-in Parameterized runner, with a Parameters method that returns 
a Collection whose size() method is a hard-coded number, and a lazily 
populated iterator().  If there turns out to be fewer elements than the 
Plan predicts, mark the remaining tests as ignored.

Is one of the community members that had this running out of memory 
problem still around on the list?  Thanks,

    David Saff
